Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Learned a TON about experimental design
From taking this course, I developed a deep insight to all things microbiology. We learned about mechanisms and purposes of microbes.
Basic knowledge in microbiology.
I learned all about bacteria, microbes, infectious diseases, viruses, experimental methods, microbiota. I learned how to design experiments.
This is honestly probably the best class in the MCDB department. I learned how to think critically and apply what I learned rather than memorize it.

Learned general microbiology concepts , structures, and specific pathways. Covered general research techniques and how those techniques (as well as more specific case studies) tie in with larger overarching concepts.
I learned a lot about lab techniques and the basics of molecular biology.
General knowledge of microbiology, including bacteriology, virology, and immunology
Learned a great deal about the microbiota.
I learned about concepts in microbiology and experimental techniques used to study microbiology.

I learned about the fundamentals of microbiology. I received an introduction to bacterial metabolism, evolutionary history, and organization/function of bacteria-specific structures. I also learned about the basics of microbiology research, including techniques to conduct basic experiments.

Learned the basic ropes of microbiology theoretical concepts  cellular parts, metabolism, host defenses  and how they can be evaluated through experimental design. Learned how to design a genetic screen and to look at pathogenicity.
Vast discoveries in microbes, all about probiotics/vaccines and pathways
Hadn't been exposed to microbiology topics before. Case studies and experimental designs were a great addition to the normal course material.

An extensive overview of microbiology from the biochemical level to practical applications and case studies. What differentiates different microbes from one another and how they behave in their abiotic and biotic environments.
I learned about the various strategies bacteria have developed to infect hosts, including mechanisms to invade host cells and subvert host functions.

I learned a lot about the details of microbial life. For example, flagellar assembly, bacterial structures (gram +-ve vs Gram -ve), experimental design (for bacterial identification, for virulence/pathogenicity evaluation), etc. This class covers broad and interesting content! There is definitely a focus on learning to set up, conduct, and interpret experiments though.
I gained insight into experimental thinking in the field of microbiology and specific information regarding microbes like bacteria and viruses.
gut microbiota, bacterial motility, koch's postulates, correlation vs. causation, screens and assays
A comprehensive overview of microbiology, focusing mostly on bacteria (anatomy, interactions, genetics, biotech, pathology) and a little bit on viruses.
A great amount of fundamental knowledge on how microbes survive and their interactions with humans

A big focus on experimental design, you learn a lot about this and bacteria.. very fun

Still, it would be helpful to have a rubric in advance of what was expected (level of detail expected for descriptions of proper controls... etc) as oftentimes lost points were not necessarily due to lack of preparation, but instead just a lack of clarity in terms of what constituted a complete answer. We were told for the first exam to not write down everything [we] know.. just the answer and then in the 2nd exam a lot more points were removed for not providing enough detail for some answers. This is not to say exams were unfair (they were generally very fair), but these sorts of things can be a little annoying at times

This course is a very effective course for teaching the material; there are no problem sets, no busy work, no extraneous text - the three midterm exams are non-cumulative and based on the lecture. As long as students attend lecture and pay attention, they have everything they need to succeed.
This course was very well taught and organized. However, it did feel rushed at some points

I think the material is very interesting especially towards the end and it is presented clearly. The exams are fair and they are not cumulative, and I love how the class draws from cell biology, biochemistry, genetics. I think it is better than other MCDB cores out there. There is no busy work, which is great. The slides are printed out in color before each class.

Strengths - not having a section lets you have more time, good teaching, good TAs

Weaknesses - good teaching but at times fast, would be nice to get slides with more info

Strengths: Fantastic course overall. Learned a ton, interesting, material, tests were well written and grading was fair, professors were great, pacing and organization great. Amazing class overall. 

Weaknesses: None really

I think a strength was that all the information needed for the exams could be found in the lecture slides that were always provided and the lecturers always paused for questions and clarified anything as well as started off every lecture with a recap.
Clear and interesting lectures, 2 TA sessions per examination, and practice exams posted
The first two sections of the course were taught very quickly and I wish some of those concepts were taught more slowly and thoroughly
The teachers were amazing, it could be improved by making the grading scaling a bit more transparent.
strengths: little coursework outside of exams, interesting lectures

This course  provides a broad introduction to microbiology, producing a tour of the entire field without going too much into depth in any one particular subtopic. The course lectures were interesting but could be disengaging as the semester went on. Both lecturers are prepared and passionate, and they succeeded when they connected with the students by providing real world examples of how course content links to modern day issues. The main issue was the opaque grading rubric for the three exams, upon which the entire gradebook is staked. I found that I did not receive clear feedback on improvements even after I had gone to the post-exam review session to talk with TAs about my exam.

The three non-cumulative exam setup was perfect for the amount of material covered on each exam, and exam content and grading were extremely fair. Lectures were engaging, and the professors were cogent and excited to introduce both concepts and research in their fields. The professors printed slides for each lecture  which was sweet and extremely helpful, given that they rely on student thoughtfulness to sit down and understand a diagram to extract information, a useful science skill.

Strength: topic material was very engaging and informative
Weakness: lack of test preparation (no sections)

Strengths: The TAs and professors were always willing to hold office hours and review sessions. Having a review session was very helpful for every four lectures. 

Weaknesses: No answers provided to the practice exams which many students understand why this was the case.

I think that while there were parts of the class were tested in a way that required the application of knowledge, much of the class is still regurgitation. While I know that it is quite difficult to write application exams in biology, I think more of the tests could be application based. However, I do enjoy that the final exam was not cumulative.

Strengths: no homework, tests, or quizzes, just three non-cumulative exams that allow you to pace yourself throughout the semester; two committed and knowledgeable professors, Jacobs-Wagner and Hatzios are quick to bring in relevant interesting outside info to supplement the material; lecture slides printed out for everyone as you walk into lecture; diverse student body from all four class years; frequent TA review sessions that are never overpopulated; recaps of the last few slides from the previous lecture

Weaknesses: very few; the biggest I think was the overall curriculum, MCDB 290 is more bacteriology than a broad-spectrum microbiology course; non-bacteria material was confined to parts of the first lecture and the last lecture about viruses. Don't get me wrong: bacteriology is a fascinating and diverse topic but I think more attention could be given to other fields within microbiology.

The strengths of this course are its amazing professors (Prof. Jacobs-Wagner and Prof. Hatzios), both of whom demonstrated a vast understanding of the field of microbiology and its applications in medicine. One weakness of this class is that there aren't discussion sections to discuss the material, so you have to study the material on your own or go to optional review sessions.

I wish that this class had Piazza or something so that students could engage with the content more. I often found that I had questions about specific slides, but the TFs are already pretty overburdened with holding office hours/review sessions that there isn't a lot of opportunity to ask exploratory questions. I think that the format as it stands - just lectures twice a week, and the only scoring coming from three midterms - is not conducive to active participation and learning. However, I think that the material is really fascinating!

Strength: Lectures fit together cohesively
Weakness: What was considered a fully correct answer on exams seemed arbitrary at times.

The course had a good pace and was broken up conceptually in a way that made sense. Office hours were available almost every day, which made them easily accessible. The independent nature of the course with no mandatory office hours was a pleasant change from other courses in the major.
Love the connections to everyday life. Wonderful professors and excellent TAs this year.

This is an amazing course in general, but the fact that the grading structure is based on only two midterms and a final is something that could be changed since that makes it very hard to obtain feedback on one's progress in learning during the year. There are regular review sessions and office hours from the TA's which are extremely helpful, but still the only comprehensive practice/feedback we get are the tests. Even something small and simple like a weekly review quiz on Canvas would be helpful.

The slides could be a little more comprehensive the second half of the year. Some of the wording on test questions was tricky and points were lost even where material was known. Great spread of topics and interesting lectures. Really nice professors.

The grading of this class is solely based off of test results, which is difficult for people who do not test well. I think this class is also designed to be easy on the TAs, because most review sessions where based off of student questions and required little work from TAs. Although there were review session, they were not always helpful if the TAs were not prepared.
well organized; lecture topics were organized with a clear progression that made all the topics make sense
Lecturers had great energy and were passionate about topics.

Definitely over cell bio or mol bio...... a relatively painless MCDB core. Just study in advance and ask questions/clarifications ahead of time and you will be golden. The professors are both very engaging and knowledgeable in their fields, I highly recommend the class to nonmajors, and especially to MCDB majors looking to fulfill a core course requirement.

Do you need a biology "gut"? If the answer is yes, this is a good course. The grading is pretty arbitrary and misses the forest for the trees (having to explicitly mention that you observe a Gram stain under light microscopy as was the case for the first midterm is silly to say the least) , but that's probably because the course is barely above high school biology in sophistication and difficulty. It's pretty easy and a breeze.

Yes, I am a non-Bio major and really loved this class. I was excited to go to class each day and never stressed about the material. My commitment mostly involved studying for one or two nights before the exams, so it was enjoyable.

I would definitely recommend it. I think microbiology is one of the fields of biology where you can actually see direct connections to your daily life. There are only three tests and they are not cumulative. There is no homework. I think this is the perfect biology class. You learn a lot, and you get assessed fairly on your knowledge. It is one of the better biology cores out there, and it is a very memeable class.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in biology or public health or cells. It was really informative and we covered a lot of topics. You will not understand everything the first time we go over it, but you will get so much help from the TAs. It was very enjoyable.

Absolutely would recommend this course. The professors (particularly Dr. Jacobs-Wagner) are incredible. Super kind, very engaging lecturers, committed to student learning, and teach well. Even though its a medium-sized lecture, they know many names by the end of the semester and reach out to the audience often. The material is interesting overall and the organization and pacing is great. The only graded assignments are three (non-cumulative) tests, which are very well written to test your knowledge and thinking skills, not just memorization. The tests are very reasonable and if you study you'll do well. Loved this course, probably my favorite STEM class at Yale so far, and it counts as an MCDB core class (at least as of 2019 Spring).
Yes, it's a good course, but don't be fooled by others claiming it was easy; you still have to put in the work to get a good grade, which i did not get for the first two exams sadly.
Yes, it is a great class that is extremely interesting and informative.
Good MCDB core course.

I would tepidly recommend this course. To an interested student, the material may be intrinsically interesting enough that somewhat disengaging and long lectures may not be a deterrent. I think that this course can provide a solid introduction to microbiology, but it may not provide material at a satisfying level of depth--there is a stronger emphasis on covering a wider range of content, which I did appreciate to an extent.
YESSS

Yes! Lovely MCDB core class, with an inspiring (all female) professor duo and interesting content. Good survey course, but also goes into signaling pathway details for those who want a bit of a niche challenge.
Wonderful course material, take if you're thinking about medicine/research
Yes, I think this is a great MCDB core course. I learned a lot and the support provided by the TAs and professors was great and not found in other classes.
A solid MCDB core with only 2 midterms and a final; no quizzes mean you have to stay on top of the material but it does lighten the workload most weeks
I would recommend this class to those in the mcdb major. I think that the content of the class is quite interesting and the class isn't too demanding.

I took MCDB 290 as a freshman and it has been one of my favorite courses so far. Material covers a wide variety of topics that have very practical implications in research, microbiology, pre-med/pre-vet. A very low commitment (yet by no means a gut) 250-level MCDB class that brings together students of all disciplines and years. Jacobs-Wagner and Hatzios are excellent and passionate in their fields, and the way they teach this class shows it. If your a student who can pace yourself on track and keep up with the material on your own, this class is perfect.

I would highly recommend Microbiology to other students, especially if they are considering taking Microbio lab, as the two classes go very well together and teach you a great deal about what bacteria and viruses are, how they infect hosts, and why they are relevant to medicine.

I would recommend this course to other students who are interested in learning about microbial life, as well as biology lab techniques/experiments to investigate microbial life. The lecture itself is pretty compelling.
Yes, this course helped me gain insight into how to think about research questions in the field of microbiology.

I highly recommend any MCDB major or anyone interested in microbiology or immunology to take this course. It was structured and taught very well, and the lectures toward the end of the course seem like a good primer to many topics in Biology of the Immune System. The topics did not feel redundant or overlap too much with other courses I have taken in the department, which I thought was a good thing.
Yes. It's a good class if you're interested in microbio.

Highly recommend! Especially if you have any interest in bacterial microbiology at all. Professor Jacobs-Wagner is amazing, both inside and outside the classroom, and MCDB290 covers so many fascinating topics about bacteria (if you're looking for fungal/protist/parasite microbiology look somewhere else though as this course is mostly bacteria plus a little bit of viruses) that are amazing to learn about. As probably mentioned by others, the grading in this class is based on two midterms and a final which is a little bit annoying; for one thing the regular workload is very little since there is no homework but for another thing you'll need to be diligent about remembering or reviewing your notes. Take lots of notes! But awesome class, makes me remember why I love biology in the first place.
yes definitely an interesting class
It is a lighter core class than others, it is not at 9am, but it is also dry in more than a few lectures.
I would recommend it for anyone looking to gain fundamental knowledge on microbes and their interactions with humans
Strong lecture course, no section
